Title:
Molecular phylogenetic species delimitation in the aquatic
genus Ottelia (Hydrocharitaceae) reveals cryptic diversity within a
widespread species
Keywords:
Alismatales; Indo-Burma; monocotyledons; new species;
species delimitation; STACEY
Abstract:
Ottelia is a genus of an aquatic plant family
Hydrocharitaceae in the tropics with many narrowly distributed taxa in
Asian tropics. Although those taxa have received comparatively more
attention than congeners in other areas (notably in Africa and South
America, for example), various key taxonomic questions remain
unaddressed, especially with regards to apparent cryptic diversity
within a widespread species. Here we test the taxonomic concepts and
evaluate species boundaries using a phylogenetic framework. We collected
virtually all species of Ottelia in the Asia-Pacific region, apart from
a small number of extremely rare species; multiple samples of Ottelia
alismoides, which represent widespread species complexes, were obtained
from India throughJapan. Molecular phylogenetic trees based on plastid
DNA and nuclear ITS showed almost identical topologies. A Bayesian
coalescent method of species delimitation using the multi-locus data set
discerned six species in the Asia-Pacific region with the highest
probability. The results lead us to conclude that certain populations in
the Asia-Pacific region represent hitherto unrecognized cryptic taxa
within widespread species complexes. Accordingly, the new species
Ottelia petiolata is described. No molecular evidence distinguishing O.
cordata and O. emersa are obtained. Therefore, the new synonymy of O.
emersa under O. cordata is proposed. Two accessions inconsistently
positioned between molecular phylogenetic trees based on plastid DNA and
nuclear ITS may be best explained by chloroplast capture.
